newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia stocks close firmer as C-C Amatil surges.
newsitem.headline: Australia stocks close firmer as C-C Amatil surges.

text.p: Australian shares ended a touch firmer for a second day running, led by a surging Coca-Cola Amatil in the wake of its A$3.4 billion (US$2.7 billin) Philippines soft drinks deal.
The benchmark All Ordinaries index ended 8.5 points firmer at 2,369.5 in moderate trade, despite a fall on Wall Street, and followed a 5.8 point rise on Thursday.
Brokers said the market was aided by early short-covering in major stocks and some bargain hunting after the sharp fall in line with Wall Street following the Easter break.
"It's not a bad performance and shows a bit of resilience, which we haven't seen for a while," said Austock Brokers research director David Perry.

C-C Amatil rose A$1.40 on the day to close at A$14.20, an 18.8 percent gain since it announced plans on Thursday to acquire San Miguel Corp soft drink subsidiary Coca Cola Bottler Philippines Inc in exchange for equity.
The strong gain surprised some brokers following suggestions by analysts that the price paid was expensive, and that the Philippines plants could require high levels of capital expenditure.
However, others said the jump had to be seen in the context of C-C Amatil's sharp fall from around A$18 late last year on earnings disappointments.
"A very good stock was really needing a bit of a blood transfusion and the market perceives that it's got that with this deal," said Intersuisse head of equities Andrew Sekely.
Elsewhere, The Broken Hill Pty Co rose five cents to A$16.99 on good volume, while takeover target The Bank of Melbourne eased three cents to A$9.47.
Brokers said the fall followed comments by Australian Treasurer Peter Costello and regulatory authorities which were seen as negative for the A$1.44 billion bid by Westpac Banking Corp.
